name: Saag Paneer
headline: Saag Paneer
description: Eat homemade Indian food tonight with Aarti Sequeira's Saag Paneer: Spinach with Indian Cheese recipe from Aarti Party on Food Network.

image.description: Aarti Sequeira's Saag Paneer for, LESSONS FROM GRANDMA/MICROWAVE VEGGIES/CHICKEN SOUP, as seen on Food Network's Aarti Party. Episode: The Big Cheese
Aarti Sequeira's Saag Paneer for, LESSONS FROM GRANDMA/MICROWAVE VEGGIES/CHICKEN SOUP, as seen on Food Network's Aarti Party. Episode: The Big Cheese
Aarti Sequeira's Saag Paneer for, LESSONS FROM GRANDMA/MICROWAVE VEGGIES/CHICKEN SOUP, as seen on Food Network's Aarti Party. Episode: The Big Cheese

keywords: Indian Recipes,Dairy Recipes,Cheese,Spinach,Vegetable,Sauteing Recipes,Gluten Free,High Fiber
recipeIngredient: 12 ounces paneer, (Indian cheese, either store-bought or made from my recipe, recipe follows), cut into 1-inch cubes, see Cook's Note*
1 (1-inch thumb) ginger, peeled and minced (about 1 tablespoon)
1 large green serrano chile, finely chopped (seeds removed if you don't like it spicy!)
1/2 teaspoon store-bought or homemade garam masala, recipe follows
1/2 cup plain yogurt, stirred until smooth
1/4 cup freshly squeezed lemon juice, plus more as needed, see Cook's Note*
3 large cinnamon sticks (if you have the kind you get at Indian stores, it's about 3 tablespoons of cinnamon bark bits)
1/4 cup green cardamom pods, shelled, husks discarded (about 2 tablespoons of seeds)
4 large black cardamom pods, shelled, husks discarded (about 1 tablespoon of seeds), optional

recipeInstructions.text: In a large bowl, whisk together the turmeric, cayenne, 1 teaspoon salt and 3 tablespoons oil. Gently, drop in the cubes of paneer and gently toss, taking care not to break the cubes if you're using the homemade kind. Let the cubes marinate while you get the rest of your ingredients together and prepped.
Thaw the spinach in the microwave in a microwave-safe dish, 5 minutes on high, then puree in a food processor until smooth. Alternatively, you can chop it up very finely with your knife.

Place a large nonstick skillet over medium heat, and add the paneer as the pan warms. In a couple of minutes give the pan a toss; each piece of paneer should be browned on one side. Fry another minute or so, and then remove the paneer from the pan onto a plate.

Add the remaining 1 1/2 tablespoons oil to the pan. Add the onions, ginger, garlic and chile. Now here's the important part: saute the mixture until it's evenly toffee-coloured, which should take about 15 minutes. Don't skip this step - this is the foundation of the dish! If you feel like the mixture is drying out and burning, add a couple of tablespoons of water.

Add the garam masala, coriander and cumin. If you haven't already, sprinkle a little water to keep the spices from burning. Cook, stirring often, until the raw scent of the spices cook out, and it all smells a bit more melodious, 3 to 5 minutes.
Add the spinach and stir well, incorporating the spiced onion mixture into the spinach. Add a little salt and 1/2 cup of water, stir, and cook about 5 minutes with the lid off.

Turn the heat off. Add the yogurt, a little at a time to keep it from curdling. Once the yogurt is well mixed into the spinach, add the paneer. Turn the heat back on, cover and cook until everything is warmed through, about 5 minutes. Serve.
Line a large colander with a large double layer of cheesecloth, and set it in your sink.

In a large wide pot, bring the milk to a gentle boil over medium heat, stirring frequently to avoid burning the bottom (a nonstick pot works really well for this purpose). This will take a little while so be patient!

Add the lemon juice and turn the heat down to low. Stirring gently, you should almost immediately see the curds (white milk solids) and whey (the greenish liquid) separate. Don't fret, this is perfect!

Remove the pot from the heat and carefully pour the contents into the cheesecloth-lined colander. Gently rinse with cool water to get rid of the lemon flavor. At this point, you could squeeze out some of the liquid, and serve with some honey and some nuts, almost like a fresh ricotta!
Grab the ends of the cheesecloth and twist the ball of cheese to squeeze out the excess whey. Tie the cheesecloth to your kitchen faucet and allow the cheese to drain for about 5 minutes.

Twisting the ball to compact the cheese into a block, place it on a plate with the twisted part of the cheesecloth on the side (this will ensure your block of cheese is nice and smooth!) and set another plate on top. Weigh the second plate down with cans of beans or a heavy pot. Move to the refrigerator and let it sit about 20 minutes.

Combine the cinnamon sticks, cloves, green cardamom seeds, black cardamom seeds, if using into a spice grinder or coffee grinder and grind until fine. Store the spice mix in an airtight container away from direct sunlight.

review.reviewBody: I have been trying to perfect saag for years and this recipe finally nailed it. I've always followed recipes that used tomatoes in the past and the texture was never right, but this one was spot on with a few adjustments, namely I doubled the dry spices and that was just right. I used 16 ounces of fresh baby spinach that I pulverized in my food processor before adding to the cooked onion/spice mixture and cooked down. I then used an immersion blender on the whole thing when it was done cooking but before adding the yogurt. I used a jalapeno instead of serrano (because that's what I had). Also, when I cut into my white onion it was bad so I used a red onion and it was perfect. I'll do that when I make this again. The only thing I messed up on was adding too much salt (maybe a tbsp or so - I just eyeballed it), which thankfully didn't ruin it but was definitely more than I'll do next time. This paneer recipe is exactly how I've always made it and it turns out perfect every time. If your milk doesn't separate when you add the first bit of lemon, just add a little more at a time and it should magically happen eventually. Thanks for the awesome recipe!

Great recipe. Only changes I made is subbing a small jalapeño for the Serrano and also adding a tsp of crushed methi leaves (fenugreek) during the last few minutes of cooking, to give it an authentic fragrance.  I also used store bought paneer.
Easy to follow steps and delicious! Better than I can get here in Iowa.

I love this recipe. I modify it slightly by adding the juice of a lime and substituting buttermilk for yogurt. Pair this with Quick Buttermilk Naan for a fantastic meal https://www.sanjanafeasts.co.uk/2019/08/quick-buttermilk-naan/

Absolutely the BEST saag paneer I've ever had! And, I've had a lot of saag paneer at Indian restaurants all over, lol. The flavors just burst from the sauce. I used a paneer from Whole Foods that was amazing - much more flavorful than most. Kudos Aarti!
Saag paneer is one of my favorite dishes! This one is particularly delicious. I use fresh spinach and chop it in the food processor before I throw it in. Chef’s kiss!
this was my first time making cheese, it is SO much less intimidating than i thought. it turned out great, i blended the spinach and added chickpeas for texture/fiber. thank you for sharing!
Saag Paneer is in my top 5 favorite dishes.  Have made this twice and am amazed how easy and delicious!

Was decent, but not amazing.

Next time I'd double the spices to make it more aromatic and double the yogurt for a better texture. It needs more serranos. I couldn't detect any spiciness. Blanch fresh spinach instead of frozen. It was too mushy.

I made chicken instead of paneer and spiced basmati rice.
Delicious. Next time I won't fry the paneer as long as recipe says - it made the texture too chewy. Other than that it was delicious. Also, "toffee-colored" is not a great descriptor

Step 4 says to add onion, pepper, garlic, and ginger all at once, but I believe that's a mistake.  The video (and common practice) is to add the ginger and garlic once the onions are already caramelized, then sauté for 30-60 seconds before quenching with wet ingredients.  Overcooked garlic will become very bitter, and overcooked ginger will become crunchy at best, and inedible at worst.
Easy and very good! Thanks!  I doubled the recipe but I put one package of tofu and 1 package of paneer.
This is my go to Saag Paneer recipe! The spices are in perfect proportion and the directions are clear and easy to follow. Introduce south-Asian cuisine to your friends with this crowd-pleasing dish!

I didn't have yogurt, so I used sour cream, and made a few other minor mistakes - but it still came out better than most of the Saag Paneer we've ordered via take out. We live in Berkeley and there are dozens of amazing Indian restaurants around here - this recipe wasn't that difficult or expensive to make and ended up being so much better than most of the places we usually order from at twice the cost.

I made this and used cayenne because I couldn't find a serrano chili. To keep the colour from being swampy, blanch baby spinach, drain and chill in ice water, then pass it through the food processor with a little lemon juice and the yogourt. It's my favourite curry and my friends loved it!

That was AMAZING!!!! The balanced flavors, the texture, all of it. The seasoning on the paneer was fantastic, especially. Even my picky teenage son scarfed it down, after looking at it rather dubiously. His eventual rating was 10/10 on flavor, 4/10 on appearance (but, to be fair, he'd rate ANY saag paneer recipe the same on appearance). My husband and I loved every part of it.
Really excellent. Quick but so tasty!
So addictive!  And I hate vegetables!  I skipped the green chili and it had plenty of flavor.

My favorite from the local Indian restaurant is Chicken Tikka Saag so I married 2 recipes, but this saag is amazing!!! So close to what I usually get, I can’t even believe it! Will definitely make again when I’m feeling ambitious
We have tried several Saag Paneer recipes and this is a true favorite. We like to use fresh spinach instead of frozen but follow everything else as is!
I make this with tofu and it’s fantastic
I've made this recipe multiple times, it's delicious and such an easy way to make paneer!
Amazing! Have made this twice. Method for cooking paneer is the best I have had. Saag is exceptional too. I used Frontier spices for garam masala.

Made this last night...I didn't puree the spinach; I know that is more like restaurant versions, but it seems like baby food to me.  I also used jalapeno peppers, since that is what I had, but the result was amazing.  I could eat the marinated paneer cubes on their own!  Served it with butter chicken and homemade naan, and the entire meal was restaurant quality.  Thanks, Aarti!

So happy I discovered this recipe before giving up on making homemade saag paneer. Since I'm already going to be washing the food processor, I decided to dump the onion, ginger, garlic and pepper in there first, before the spinach step. For me, chopping the onion, etc. in the food processor yields such a nice consistency for the final texture of the dish--it's more like restaurant saag paneer, and less like a stir fry.
Thank you! This was delicious!!

My paneer, paneered out. It never separated. The instructions say to add the lemon juice and reduce heat to low...for how long? I let it barley simmer after adding lemon juice for 20 min, just a thick mess. Tried again, reduce to low added the lemon juice and same result. Flavor was good, had to substitute with potatoes. Would I make again probably not. Lost a full gallon of milk today :(

Oh my, this was delicious! Worth the time to make. We did get paneer from a local Indian market. Delicious. A thousand times better than any frozen, “pouch” version of  saag paneer. Better than most Indian restaurants where I live
Wow! This was delicious.  I made the homemade paneer.  Easy and superb!

Thank you Aarti! I come back to this recipe time and time again.  Despite always making a double-batch, my partner and I still beg, bargain and wrestle each other for the leftovers. It's delicious and tastes even better for lunch the next day.   I use spices (fresh and dried) from my local Indian grocery, including dried DEEP red pepper (extra spicy) [cayenne] and it turns out with a deep, rich spice level with the recommended spice quantities (compares to "medium" hot level of typical authentic Indian restaurants in my area).  We like our food pretty spicy so I make sure to use fresh serrano peppers including the seeds and double the dried spice quantities.  The spice level does not disappoint.  Key to full-bodied flavor is to take the time to let the onions, garlic and ginger carmelize and to allow the dry spices time over the heat to open up. Overall, this is an approachable recipe for even a less-experienced home cook using techniques and equipment available in most American home kitchens and provides reliable flavor and texture.  I have made homemade paneer and it's good. But I prefer the firmness and texture of a store-bought block for this recipe (contrasts nicely with the soft saag texture).

This is SO good.  My husband is Indian and this was my first attempt at cooking a traditional Indian dish- he loved it.  I ended up making the paneer, and I was surprised how simple it was to make.  Great flavor and spice, and I followed ingredients list as it is.

Turned out well - used store-bought paneer, fresh spinach (run through the food processor), and doubled ALL spice levels... still not authentically spicy. Only had greek yogurt so used that instead. *I would recommend adding a splash of acid (lemon juice or apple cider vinegar) to this as it came out a little bland on its own.
Tasted awesome and was easy to make!
Prep time was definitely not 10 minutes, but this recipe is delicious.
Phenomenal recipe!  Much better than what you receive in most restaurants.

A great recipe.  I do however up the spice level about twice as much because I like to live dangerously, especially while marinating the paneer!  I made it last year for Thanksgiving and it was a hit so doing it again!
Delicious!
Not great. The spices are weak compared to what I've eaten made by Indian chefs. This was written for Americans.
This remains my favorite saag paneer recipe of all time. I come back to it over and over. Thank you!

Just love this dish!
Just love this dish delicious and satisfying! Perfect with naan bread or rice!
This turned out delicious.  I bought paneer at a local Indian store and used fresh spinach.  Will make again!
So bland. I have no idea why this has so many good reviews. Really lacking in flavor. I don't know what it's missing but this recipe is not one I'll be trying again.

This recipe is PERFECTION!!  Last time I made it I didn’t follow directions properly.  This time I did all my chopping and measuring before hand so that I could go slow and do it right.  Store-bought paneer did way better than my crumbly version,  cubed up perfectly and browned so well. I did half Greek yogurt and half heavy cream.  YUM.
My fave saag paneer so far. Today I used Warrigal greens, silver beet, Russian and Tuscan kales for the greens. Turned out delicious  Thanks

Aarti does NOT disappoint! She makes dishes so accessible, and it felt so good to totally make this meal from start to finish. We just savored every bite with so much joy. We will DEFINITELY make this again!
This was delicious! I made this with Aarti's Naan. Yum!
This was great. I was nervous because it says the onion mix is the most important part and I didn’t have any onion. I used a red pepper in place of the onion and it still tasted wonderful.
This recipe is amazing! I used the marinade for the paneer to cook the onions,Serrano peppers, garlic and ginger and turned out amazing.

This turned out great! I had to add a bit more yogurt to make it closer to "my liking", but that's how I'm used to it based on my favorite Indian spot. The paneer, especially after marinating in that oil, was amazing!! Thanks Aarti!

Have now made this twice, once with frozen spinach and once using fresh baby spinach. It was excellent both times although I think I am partial to the fresh spinach. What was game changing for me was using an immersion blender on the spinach - did this right in the large wok that I cooked the dish in and so much easier than having to blend separately. Getting the spinach very fine is critical to the texture and flavor of the dish. Otherwise, pretty much followed the recipe as is. Served with the chicken tikka masala recipe from this site as well as homemade flatbreads.
We love this dish! We have this with chicken tikka masala and it's our new comfort food! We make it per the recipe using Costco paneer cheese with a jalapeño and it’s perfect!
This was so good! The homemade paneer was delicious and super easy. I loved the spice level and I will be using this recipe again!
This was perfect. I have tried and failed to make a solid saag paneer or palak paneer many times from different recipes, but this one is perfect and (relative to what I get in restaurants) healthy!
I love this dish. I have made it several times and it's perfect every time. It has become comfort food!

OMG, this was SO. GOOD. Palak Paneer is one of my favorite dishes! I liked having the spinach have some texture instead of a puree. The only change I made to the recipe was using half Greek yogurt (plain, full fat) and half heavy cream as the yogurt was quite tangy. It was perfect. This was well worth the time and effort!!!
Very flavorful! I think it was a good idea for the paneer to be marinated. I ended up using jalapeno peppers since I couldn't find serrano peppers. There was still a little kick and it wasn't bad. :)

I followed the recipe exactly except I had no hot pepper and so I substituted red pepper flakes. The dish was wonderful! I had fun making the paneer, too! What would be some good dishes to accompany this in a menu for a party?

My wife and I are big fans of Indian cuisine. I made this recipe twice and while it tasted decent the first time it was definitely missing something and the flavours just weren't fully rounded out.

I should have known that the secret was the same thing that makes my Chili's taste perfect... Sugar. I read in the comments that someone added brown sugar. I added about a teaspoon or two to the entire mix and that was exactly what it needed to balance the heat, bitterness and salt.

Pair with some basmati and paratha and bam, an easy killer dish to make with tons of flavour.

I prepared it for the first time and it was delicious. I added a little more salt at the end which surprised me b/c I tend to under salt things. We will be putting this dish in our regular rotation. Once I make it a few times it will be a cinch to throw together. I’ll look for more of her recipes. Thanks, Aarti

I love Indian food and been to India 5 times. This recipe was super disappointing and bland. I had to add 2 additional teaspoons of spice to make it taste somewhat like an Indian dish. And even with that it lacked something I can't figure out. It's frustrating because I feel Indian dishes are watered down in America for fear of spice. I agree with the other posts that yogurt is not the way to go with this. I did a mix of Buttermilk and Cream. I added a bit of lemon juice at the end to add some acid, but I won't be making this version of Saag again.

I followed the recipe exactly, and it was absolutely amazing!  I served it on cauliflower rice, which really enhanced the flavors of the saag.  Using plain yogurt instead of heavy cream makes it taste so much better than the saag we get in Indian restaurants, where the spinach is floating in a bath of way too much cream!  After eating Indian take-out, my stomach never feels good, but after eating this homemade version, my husband and I were amazed at how good we felt!  Adding brown sugar and/or heavy cream is not necessary! This recipe is perfect as written!

First, I want to say that Saag Paneer is my second favorite subzi (veg) dish. Like a couple of the other reviewers, I found that adding the yogurt ruined the taste. It made it overly tart and didn't have the normal creamy feel. My husband, who is Indian and from MP, said that was unsurprising to him. He recommended that I cut it through with some brown sugar, heavy cream, and more garam masala. It worked! He saved this dish.

I gave four stars because everything else was perfect. I know some people used Greek yogurt and maybe that was what made the difference in their dish. Next time, I'll cut it with heavy cream since I know that works. Rather take the extra fat than have an unpalatable meal!

For fresh spinach chop and blanch 250g. Drain while you marinade and sear the paneer.
I recommend using 1 tsp-2 tsp cayenne depending on tolerance and how hot your pepper is.
Cook onion for a few minutes before adding ginger and a few minutes more before the minced garlic.
Puree spinach with half the onion mixture and 3/4 cup of vegetable stock.
Return to pan. You could even add a little extra veggie stock to the pan first. 
Add yoghurt and paneer

Marinating and frying the  paneer is the thing that makes this Saag Paneer recipe so special.  I was skeptical at first about this procedure,, but after trying other recipes for Saag Paneer,  I found this recipe to be the best.   The flavor of the marinated paneer is the thing that brings this dish to a new level.    I have tried other recipes, but this is the best.   I used paneer bought at Whole Foods, and it worked very well.
This was easy and absolutely delicious, I followed the recipe exactly.  I will be making it again.
My family loved this recipe, even my "picky" 7 year old!  Does any one have the nutritional info for this recipe?  I can't seem to find it anywhere!
I followed this recipe to the T and it was terribly bland. I was highly disappointed because I was really craving this dish.

Easy to follow recipe and it turned out to be delicious!  I used Greek yogurt and it worked very well.  I also added sautéed mushrooms (because I really like them) at the same time I added the spinach into the onion mixture.
This is incredible. I did use greek yogurt and tofu instead of paneer to make it a little healthier. This makes a nice big batch so I had one question- does it freeze well? Thanks!!
Not sure what a melody of smells is but I'm thinking melodious and harmonious are  similar.....either way this is delicious......thank you....

We make this every week at our house! Great recipe to get your fill of green leafies :)

5 stars! Go Aarti!

Just have to say...I never believed I could make saag before but I just enjoyed an incredible saag meal thanks to this recipe.  I used 24 oz of fresh spinach instead of frozen, tofu instead of paneer, and greek yogurt, other than that followed the recipe to a tee and was absolutely amazed with how authentic the flavors were.  Thank you!!!

Super fresh and yummy! If you use frozen spinach, it has more water than fresh so it won't be too thick as others pointed out. And definitely use food processor to make it super fine or it's just not the same. I would assume you'd need more water in that step if you use fresh. But yum! Used 2% greek yogurt (vs reg because that's what I had. It was totally fine and gave it a hint of extra taste.) Added chickpeas to mine as well for a little more protein but just as delicious!
Just made this tonight! Loved it!

I used to buy a frozen version of palak paneer which was good but was loaded with salt.  So, I came across this recipe and had a go at it since I already had most of the ingredients. It was excellent!  I followed it almost exactly as written except I used fresh spinach which I had to blanch first.  I also made the paneer lactose free (for a friend) by using lactose free whole milk.  It worked out beautifully as well.  I have to stop myself from gobbling up the paneer after it's marinated and fried as it tastes good all by itself.  I did not make my own garam masala but used a version purchases from an organic grocer.

I encourage anyone who likes palak paneer to give it a try.  Oh, it's even better the next day after the flavors have had time to blend.
the best palak paneer recipe that I have used and continue to use
Super, fabulous cheese- so tender and delicious. Next time I will use fresh spinach, which I think will elevate it even more.
I have never made saag paneer before. I have made this recipe at least 3 times now. I love it! I'm actually making some tonight. I even made the naan bread too. So so good!
Very very good recipe. Thanks Aarti. The dish is practically restaurant-quality. Next time, might add a little bit of heavy cream as well.

I made this last night, substituted chicken for paneer, marinated the chicken in the yogurt and garam masala.  I added more chili then recommended and pureed the spinach.  This is the best saag recipe that I have used. So good I had to eat the leftovers for breakfast!

Made this the other day - it was awesome.  The one thing I wish I had done differently is puree the spinach in a food processor instead of chopping by hand (secondary option).  Definitely pull out that food processor.    Recipe is amazing as written.

So delicious and such an easy recipe. Pretty much fool proof. That goes for making the paneer, too. Although, beware, it took me about 30 minutes at least to get it boiling. Also, next time I will add 1.5 tsp garam masala, opposed to just the .5 tsp the recipe calls for. Love me some garam masala.
Amazing recipe. Can't wait to make it again.
Made it exactly as the recipe states and it's the best Saag Paneer I've ever had!
Have made this a couple of times now. The only thing I have changed is to add some chilli powder to the sauce; this can be done at the end of cooking to adjust to taste.
I really enjoyed this recipe!

I made this last night with store bought Paneer.  The cheese was very good, but I tried to follow Aartie's recipe for garam masala and it was just way too much clove.  I didn't even use as much as she recommended, so I think if Ihad used a store bought garam masala, we would have enjoyed much more.  It is one of our favorite indian recipe's, so I think I'll let my husband do his own thing in the future, his is really pretty darned good, and very close to what we get at the Indian restaurant here.

If you like authentic Indian food or spicy food, then double or triple the amount of chile used. The amount of spice in this recipe is way, way off. 

The consistency of the blended spinach is unappealing. Saag should be somewhere between thick and runny, and this recipe makes it thick thick thick. To fix this, after mixing the blended spinach with the onion/spice mixture, I removed 3/4 of it from the pan and put it back into the food processor with 3/4 cup veggie stock and blended it more. Then I mixed it back into the pan. Not only does this make the texture more appealing, but blending the onions, garlic, and ginger helps spread the flavor throughout the dish rather than have it appear in clumps. 

Finally, I veganized my paneer by using tofu instead. To get a cheesy texture, cure the tofu in salt overnight in the fridge, then let it soak in the juice from 1 lemon for a few hours. Then cut into cubes and follow the recipe as normal, making sure to fry until the sides are crispy. 

I would definitely make this recipe again, but not without fixing the spice and consistency.

This is a wonderful recipe! As I review a couple of other comments, I agree that it is very hot, as I tend to like it. Maybe just reduce the amount of chile. The flavors are bold and the dish is filling. I used fresh spinach and happened to have Chinese mustard greens, so added that to the spinach which may have offered a little more texture to the dish (which I liked). But, try the recipe as is. I am confident you'll enjoy this if you like authentic full-flavored Indian cuisine.

video.name: Aarti's Saag Paneer
video.description: Spinach and marinated cheese is combined in this spicy Indian dish.
